content: The elusive Mr. Hyde exhibits a certain duality in what novel by Robert Louis Stevenson?

The elusive Mr. Hyde is a central character in the novel "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" by Robert Louis Stevenson. This novella, first published in 1886, explores themes of good and evil, duality in human nature, and the consequences of scientific experimentation on the human psyche. The story revolves around the protagonist, Dr. Henry Jekyll, who creates a potion that transforms him into the sinister and impulsive Edward Hyde. Through this transformation, Stevenson delves into the darker aspects of human nature and the struggle between morality and baser instincts. The novel has become a classic in English literature and has been adapted numerous times in various media, including films, plays, and other literary works.
